utterances: The city council here is exploring several ideas including subsidized housing for teachers and others who can't afford local rents, but make too much to qualify for low-income housing.

Silicon Valley teacher Tara Hunt says she knows some parents of children she teaches are sympathetic, but she's not sure they really get it.

Many communities have made it a crime to sleep outside, panhandle or feed large groups of people in public.

Homeless advocates say these laws criminalize everyday activities by those who have nowhere else to live, and they're now getting crucial support from the courts and from the Obama administration, as NPR's Pam Fessler reports.
In recent weeks, work crews in Honolulu have dismantled wooden shacks and tents that line city streets and housed almost 300 people.
It's the latest city trying to deal with a growing homeless population and respond to complaints that such encampments are unsafe, unsanitary, and at the very least, unsightly.
Other camps have been cleared in Oregon and Montana, and last month, Madison, Wis., banned people from sleeping outside city hall.
In New Port Richey, Fla., the city council just voted to restrict the feeding of homeless individuals in a popular park.
Debbie Manns is city manager.
We received complaints from the regular users of the park, who felt that it was intimidating or, you know, they were leaving behind a mess, which was true and we had to clean that up.

And according to the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, cities have been passing such laws with increasing frequency in recent years, restricting outdoor sleeping, begging and other activities linked to homelessness.
However, there have been some positive developments just in the last couple of months, and some of those are starting to have an impact.
Maria Foscarinis runs the center.
She notes that in August, the U.S.
Department of Justice filed a brief in a case challenging an anti-camping ordinance in Boise, Idaho.
The department said that such laws are unconstitutional if individuals have nowhere else to stay.

And then a few weeks later, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that it will consider what steps a community's taking to prevent the criminalization of homelessness when it awards $1.9 billion in new homeless assistance grants.
We can't really fight these battles city by city, and it's like putting out fires.
Now with the federal government taking a stance, I think we really have a chance of turning the ship around.
And there are signs that's beginning to happen.
Several California communities have stopped enforcing their anti-camping laws to consider alternatives.
And in Colorado last month, Denver, Colorado Springs and Boulder suspended panhandling ordinances after a federal judge ruled that one such law was unconstitutional because it violated free speech.
Sarah Huntley is a spokesperson for the city of Boulder.
Based on the advice of our city attorney we made a determination that it would be a prudent move to scale back some of the provisions we had, specifically related to how we define aggressive begging.
And the city has since revised its law.
Advocates say they can understand why communities are frustrated having people begging, sleeping, and in some cases defecating in public.
But Foscarinis says throwing them in jail doesn't solve the problem.
We agree.
People should not be living in public.
What we're saying is the response should not be to make it a crime.
The response should be to ensure that people have a place to live.
And indeed, many communities are trying to pair enforcement with more positive efforts to get people off the streets.
Scott Morishige is homelessness coordinator for the state of Hawaii.
He says the city and state sent workers out to help those in the street find places to live before the Honolulu camp was torn down.

And we're really trying to do everything we can to provide an array of supports so that individuals living in encampments have opportunities to move not only into shelter, if they so choose, but also into permanent housing.
He says they succeeded with about half the residents.
They're now turning their attention to the others.
Many of them moved to a new camp that sprung up in a nearby park.
Pam Fessler, NPR News.

Did you see people who were happy to come into the classroom and serve you?

What do you, as a student, think of this whole issue of teacher tenure?
Well, personally, I believe that students--well, let's start from the top.
I mean, I was looking at a statistic online from the State Office of Administrative Hearings.
In the Los Angeles Unified School District from 1990 to 1999, only 13 dismissal panels were convened, and just one tenured teacher's case went through the dismissal process from beginning to end.
I find it hard to fathom that there was only one bad teacher in the second largest school district in the country.
The tenure process is so bureaucratic, and personally, I've had personal experience with teachers who, you know, basically say, `I'm only teaching for the money.
You guys can't get rid of me.'
I mean, I can recall quite vividly a particular teacher saying, you know, `You guys can't get rid of me' and, you know, he just acted with impunity.
And I think that, you know, if you look at any other job industry, almost none guarantee lifetime job security after only two years of competence.
And the tenure process is so bureaucratic that, you know, it's kind of hard to get rid of bad teachers.
It's so expensive.
It's time-consuming.
And the stat that I gave a second ago basically shows that it's really, really hard to get rid of bad teachers, and it should be a lot easier.
Let me turn back to you, Joseph.
Yes.
The whole question--here, you've been hearing from a student, obviously very well-versed on the topic.
Only one dismissal in that record that he found.
I think Sharon's point is obviously very well-taken, that there's not enough of a focus on good teachers.
But how do you contextualize this whole move to end teacher tenure with everything that's going on in California?
There's also a very contentious budget proposal that would cut the education budget in California.
Would there be a bargain struck, you think, with California teachers--would say, `OK, well, yeah, we'll end teacher tenure, but we want X, Y and Z'?
Is there going to be some process of bargaining in California to try to improve the education system, but are teachers willing to give on any of these points?
Well, you know, that is such a political hot-button.

I'm sure there's going to be some sort of agreements between the governor and the unions, but, you know, that's the problem, I think, is that we're centering all this in a political arena, making decisions based upon political expediency and support, rather than on what is best for our students.

It seems to me that both the unions, both the--all the stakeholders--unions, boards of educations, the governor, all legislators--should be focusing on the student and what's best for them, not on the political leverage that they can gain by making a particular deal.
That goes along with the suit that's going on with the union suing the governor over the funding.
We need to break through those walls and pull education out of the political area and work for the benefit of our students.
That is the most important aspect.
And I don't understand why all our stakeholders can't come to the table and can't be focusing on that aspect of teaching.
And I would like to comment about Sharon's comment about having our excellent teachers helping the newer teachers.
In our Beginning Teacher Support and Assessment program, that's exactly what we do.

We're able to take our veteran teachers--we actually give them additional training and coaching techniques, working with adults, and link them with a new teacher, and that is paying great dividends for us and allowing us to grow some quality teachers and, at the same time, actually--in some cases, it actually pumps up the quality of our veteran teachers, because now they see some of the--maybe it's the little holes that they have in their own instruction.
So I agree completely with Sharon that we need to be looking at our veteran teachers and how they can help us grow our younger teachers.
I want to move on to a couple more topics in the Roundtable today.
First off, middle school.
Some research suggests that students really lose their way when they move from a smaller elementary school classroom to a larger middle school one.
How do you think, Sharon--and I'll go to you--how do you think schools should be structured in terms of how children progress from different types of schools to the next?
My mother was a middle school teacher.
She's now retired, but, you know, she told me a lot of stories.
The kids are old enough to get into a lot of trouble and young enough not to necessarily make the best judgment calls.
Is there an alternative, for example?
I think we need to have these classes.
There's not enough room in the history books.
In history classes, we used to get as far as World War II.
An awful lot has happened since World War II.
And there's not enough time to teach the American history necessary from September to June.
So a separate class in ethnic history and culture is absolutely essential in our 21st world.
Jarell, briefly.
The name was his suggestion.

Indeed.
I do it all the time.
I have taught in all configurations of schools, and I think if you stay in education long enough, every 20 years, there's a new wave of `this is the way that this is going to work.
I've been through schools with walls and without walls, block scheduling and traditional scheduling, middle school, junior high, high school.
So I don't think it's the combination of age groups that we put together, but I think what's more important is the way that the school is done.

If we have a middle school, where the kids are just warehoused and there's no support, there's no nurturing, there's nothing that can help them to grow as individuals as well as learn the academic materials, then that school is going to fail.
If you have a K-8 configuration with the same problem, you have bearded eighth-graders in a building with five-year-olds, which is not good.
So each of them have their negatives.
I think if we focus on the strengths within a school--I think the small school concept is excellent.
I think the teaming concept is excellent.

And if we have smaller contingencies so that the teachers get to know the students, know who they are, know how--that they function in--academically as well as socially, that the K-8 school can be extremely successful, and the middle school can be successful, the junior high can be successful.
But it depends on the grouping of the students, the teaming of the students and the focus on their academic and social needs.
Jarell, what about you?
You know, what kind of middle school or junior high school did you go to?
What sorts of issues do you think that the students could have used help with and who could have provided that?
Well, you know, I believe that the transition between fifth and sixth grade was just really, really difficult.
I went to a traditional middle school, sixth through eighth, and I just totally think that that concept can be worked on.
While I was on the Board of Education in Trenton, most of the issues we were dealing with were in terms of test scores, in terms of safety, in terms of, you know, a lot of issues.
We focused on middle school.
That transition between elementary school to middle school is just harsh.
Like dealing with--you know, sixth grade, you have a lot more freedom, more classes, more teachers, and I just think that the blow can be lessened if we went to a K-through-eighth school.
It just seems like teachers, in those particular settings, are a lot more comfortable with the students and there's a better relationship.

It's just a little too hard to jump from fifth to sixth.
And, Joseph, let me ask you, you're working with new teachers, trying to develop their skills.
Yeah.
One of the things that I've heard from many different teachers is that they are expected, particularly in middle school, to be social workers, not just to be teachers.
They have to deal with kids whose parents may have substances abuse problems, kids who are beginning to have sex.
All of these issues are really coming into play in the middle school years.
What do you tell your new teachers about how to deal with some of these bigger social issues?

Well, I think that, to be quite frank and after 10 years at the middle school as a teacher, I can tell you that the middle school student is quite--a little bit crazy, because of the hormones that course through their body.
However, with our new teachers, we have to let them know that they're teaching the whole person, and if there are issues that get in the way of their learning, then we must deal with those issues.
And, you know, just to say, `Well, the student is here in my class.
I have a subject to teach,' I think those are the kinds of teachers who really don't belong at the middle school level.

There's a certain quality to an effective middle school teacher that recognizes the challenges of that student, who recognizes, as Jarell said, the transitional problems that exist, and are willing to work with that child.
I think the middle school years are more about the social, more about attitudes, quite frankly, than it is the content.
